p: Arguably, the two major sources of inorganic carbon to Lake Superior are atmospheric CO 2 influx (owing to its large surface area; ∼82,000 km 2) and dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) from rivers and streams. Lake Δ 14C DIC tracks atmospheric Δ 14C CO2 values rather than riverine Δ 14C DIC values 21. Therefore, changes in watershed factors such as soil respiration that could influence lake DIC δ 13C values through time are likely negligible.
